title: 113_hr2903
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS." is a condensed summary of the section's title and its findings. The "National Collegiate Athletics Accountability Act" or the "NCAA Act" acknowledges the significant amount of funding institutions of higher education receive annually under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, including Federal Pell Grants. This funding is crucial for providing grants, loans, and work-study funds to students. Athletic programs at institutions of higher education generate significant revenue through various sources, totaling approximately $6.1 billion. This includes funds from ticket sales, media rights, alumni donations, and association distributions. The Committee on Sports Medicine classified sports based on contact likelihood. Contact/collision sports include boxing, football, and wrestling. Limited-contact/impact sports include basketball, gymnastics, and volleyball. SEC. 2. PROGRAM PARTICIPATION AGREEMENTS. Section 487(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include requirements for annual baseline concussion testing of student athletes in intercollegiate athletic programs. The amendment to Section 487(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 includes provisions for formal administrative hearings, appeals, and due process procedures for student athletes and institutions before enforcing any remedy for policy violations. The remedy must be put on hold until all appeals are exhausted or the deadline to appeal has passed. The Higher Education Act amendment ensures that athletically related student aid for contact/collision sport athletes is guaranteed for up to 4 years, cannot be revoked based on athletic skill or injury, and allows institutions to pay stipends to student athletes. Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 does not apply to activities of higher education institutions to comply with nonprofit athletic association membership requirements.
